question: The Voyager II space probe was launched in 1979 with the mission of flying past the outer gas giant planets and collecting data.  What unit of measurement would BEST describe the distance that this probe traveled to reach Neptune?
What are the only objects in the solar system that generate light, created by reactions deep inside their core?
Our solar system is located ____________ the Milky Way galaxy.
The Kuiper Belt is a region of the Solar System that exists past the orbit of Neptune.  What unit of length is the most logical choice for measuring the Kuiper Belt distances?
Alpha Centauri is one of the closest star systems to our Solar System.  What would be the best unit of measurement to show this distance?

Some localized layers of rock contain the element iridium. Iridium is most often found in space objects such as meteoroids and asteroids. The discovery of these iridium-containing layers has been matched to which phenomena in Earth's history?
Which of the following is the name for a cloud of dust and gas in space?
All these statements concerning galaxies are accurate except
answerB: Most can be seen without a telescope.
answerC: They are millions of light-years apart.

question: In 2004 the Hubble space telescope captured images of distant star clusters, each containing about a million stars. These star clusters were most likely part of which structure?
When calculating distance in space, planets appear to move __________ stars.
Which of these is only found outside the solar system?

Helen is preparing a presentation about objects in the solar system. She includes facts about the order of the planets and their distances from the Sun. Which statement could she include in an accurate presentation?
answerA: Mars is closer to the Sun than Earth.
answerB: Neptune is one light-year from the Sun.
answerC: Jupiter is farther from the Sun than Uranus.
answerD: Earth is one astronomical unit from the Sun.

question: Earth is located on the outer edge of the disc-shaped __________ galaxy.

The change in the use of one model of the solar system to the use of another model resulted in major changes in science and society. Which two scientists produced the earlier and later models, respectively?
__________ is made up of a large collection of stars, gas, and dust, held together by gravity.
A large, solid spherical body in the solar system is classified as a moon. Which characteristic of the body gives it this classification?
answerD: It reflects light from a star.

question: The eight known planets accreted during the formation of our solar system. The four inner planets are rocky and have little or no atmospheres. The four outer planets have very thick atmospheres. Which fact about our early solar system best helps explain how these different planet types formed?
answerA: The outer planets were too far from the Sun for solar pressure to maintain compressed gases.
answerB: The outer planets each absorbed most of the gases from their large number of moons.
answerC: The temperature near the Sun was too great for most gases to condense on the inner planets.
answerD: The gravitational forces from the outer planets pulled away the gases from the inner planets.

question: The current structure of the solar system implies which conclusion about its history?
answerA: The nebular cloud flattened before planetary formation.
answerB: Planetary temperatures were much more uniform until recently.
answerC: Matter began to revolve around its center after planetary formation.
answerD: Nuclear fusion was much more widespread before planetary formation.

question: Which of the following describes the sun?
answerA: The sun is a star made up of rocky material.
answerB: The sun is a star that is the same size as all the other stars in the sky.
answerC: The sun is a star and is the center of our solar system.
answerD: The sun is a planet and is the center of our solar system.

question: As our solar system formed, how did the higher proportion of radioactive elements in the protoplanets influence planetary development?
answerA: It reinforced the compression caused by gravity.
answerB: It powered the motion of planets toward their final orbits.
answerC: It provided a heat source to help drive layer differentiation.
answerD: It altered the elements so planets would have the same compositions.

question: Direct observation has shown the Moon's composition is overall similar to Earth's mantle. This similarity has been interpreted as supporting which theory?
answerA: The Moon formed from the same material as the outer planets.
answerB: The Moon formed by the capture of a large asteroid from the asteroid belt.
answerC: The Moon formed by splitting off from an Earthlike planet in a similar solar system.
answerD: The Moon formed from material ejected during a collision of the early Earth with another planet.

question: Scientists observed ice as a component of comets. This observation reinforced which model of the history of our solar system?
answerA: Most planets in our solar system originally had water oceans.
answerB: Comets delivered some of the water found in Earth's oceans.
answerC: Solar system planetary cores are generally a mix of iron and water.
answerD: Most of the water in our solar system migrated to comets over time.

question: In the solar system, moons orbit planets. Which of these do planets orbit?
A scientist is searching for areas where new solar systems might form. What feature is the scientist looking for?
answerA: a star similar to our Sun
answerB: a cloud of dust and gas

question: The formation of the planets, moons, stars, and solar systems into a spherical shape is due to the __________.
Different units of measurement are more useful in some settings than in others. Which unit of measurement is most used when comparing distances within the solar system?
The gravitational force of the Sun affects the planets in our solar system. Which of these is influenced the most by this force?
answerD: the number of moons per planet

question: Uranus is one of the outer planets of the solar system. The average distance of Uranus from the Sun is 2.87 billion kilometers. Which best explains why Uranus revolves in its orbit instead of moving out into space?
answerA: The orbit of Neptune limits Uranus.
answerB: Gravity pulls Uranus toward the Sun.
answerD: Other planets have the same mass as Uranus.

question: Although no other known planet in our solar system can support life as it exists on Earth, there are characteristics that make some planets more suitable than others for supporting artificial environments in which humans could live. Which planet is best suited for an artificial human habitat?
answerA: Venus, which has an average surface temperature of 864Â°F
answerB: Jupiter, which radiates twice as much heat as it absorbs from the Sun
answerC: Mars, which possibly has frozen water under the surface
answerD: Saturn, which is composed mostly of hydrogen and helium

question: In the 1500s, Nicolaus Copernicus proposed a new theory on the heliocentric structure of the solar system. Which of these statements best describes this new theory?
answerA: Earth is at the center of the solar system.
answerB: There are eight planets in the solar system.
answerC: The Sun is at the center of the solar system.
answerD: Moons have circular orbits in the solar system.

question: Based on the evidence available at the time, early models of the solar system stated that all objects in space orbited Earth. In the 16th century, an astronomer reevaluated the evidence and proposed a model of the solar system that is still in use. What part of this model corrected the mistake in previous solar system models?
answerA: The Sun is at the center of this model.
answerB: Earth is the largest object in this model.
answerC: This model contains more than one star.
answerD: This model shows that Earth is stationary.

question: The Heliocentric Theory, as supported by Copernicus, revolutionized scientific theories regarding
Why are rock samples from the moon helpful in determining the relative age of the solar system?
answerA: because moon rocks have not gone through changes caused by tectonic activity
answerB: because moon rocks have gone through changes caused by tectonic activity
answerC: because moon rocks came from a distant solar system
answerD: because moon rocks by their nature change over time
